item.title: Using Firebase for Storage
item.description: Using Firebase for Storage A quick and easy way to set up your own annotation store without managing your own server is through Firebase, a web application development platform by Google. Firebase includes a cloud-based document database with a JavaScript SDK for storing, updating and deleting JSON records. All you need to do is wire up the Firebase storage SDK operations with the corresponding events from Annotorious. E.g. when Annotorious fires the createAnnotation event, store the annotation via the .

item.title: Contributing UI Translations
item.description: We want to make Annotorious available in as many languages as possible. If you want to help: providing a translation is easy - and because Annotorious doesn’t have many labeled user interface elements, it’s also not a lot of work. How to add a new translation The user interface labels are part of the recogito-client-core package, located here. In this folder you will find messages files, one for each available translation.

item.title: Hacker's Guide
item.description: When working on RecogitoJS or Annotorious, you may sometimes need to modify code in recogito-client-core. To make this work, you have to npm link your local projects. Clone the RecogitoJS and/or Annotorious repositories Clone the recogito-client-core repository Run npm install in all repositories to install dependencies Link your local clone of recogito-client-core, so that changes you make to recogito-client-core are reflected in RecogitoJS/Annotorious $ cd recogito-client-core $ npm install $ npm link # Creates a global symlink $ cd .
